title: Thursday, 7th September, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:00am

PM11:01am

PM11:01am

PM11:03am

PM11:04am

PM11:04am

11:04 am
PM11:04am

You'll have to click to enjoy that

undefined
PM11:05am

ECB, ECB, ECB -- my inbox is full of Draghi stuff, which basically all says he'll say very little, nothing will change. Yet.

11:04 am
PM11:05am

Which I guess is why the euro is on a tear

PM11:05am

Threatening to go through 1.20

PM11:05am

I will just throw some grey up

11:05 am
PM11:05am

Reinhard Cluse -- UBS

PM11:06am

ECB to stay put on 7 September, delay tapering decision to 26 OctoberWe think the ECB will not make a specific tapering decision on 7 September, but explicitly delay this to the next meeting on 26 October. Instead, the focus of next week's meeting will be on the ECB's new staff macroeconomic forecasts. We think the key reason for staying put on 7 September is the sharp (more than 5%) rise in EUR/USD since late June – a move that the ECB will not want to turbo-charge through additional hawkish rhetoric. Trying to adjust its communication relatively little suggests to us that the ECB might well keep the QE easing bias in place next week

PM11:06am

This is from a few days ago -- but still relevant

11:06 am
PM11:06am

How will Draghi comment on the Euro?In our view, one of the biggest questions for next week's meeting is how ECB President Draghi will comment on the Euro. As we see it, Mr Draghi has a big dilemma. Presumably, he wanted to sound dovish after the last ECB meeting on 20 July, in order to reverse some of the tightening in financial conditions that had ensued since his Sintra speech on 27 June. But instead, the Euro rallied hard after his press conference, potentially aided by his own unwillingness to explicitly express discomfort about the currency levels, but also the subsequent lack of comments on the Euro by other GC members. Against this background, we would not be surprised if Mr Draghi were to become a bit more explicit that further upward pressure on the Euro is unwelcome from the ECB's point of view. He will likely reiterate that the ECB does not target the exchange rate, but would have to react to a stronger currency to the extent that it puts downward pressure on inflation.

PM11:07am

This is Draghi key problem -- trying to talk the currency down, which out saying anything

PM11:07am

Tapering as of Jan 2018, but ECB unlikely to pre-commit to a strict time-frameFundamentally, our monetary policy outlook remains unchanged: Given solid Eurozone growth, sentiment at multi-year highs, reduced political uncertainty, and anticipation of growing technical challenges to the QE programme in 2018, we expect the ECB to start tapering QE as of January 2018. But we think the ECB will avoid a strong upfront announcement on the time span of tapering, in order to maintain flexibility to act in a data-dependent way and not send an overly hawkish signal to the markets. More specifically, we expect the ECB to announce on 26 October that it will cut its monthly asset purchases from €60bn to €40bn as of January 2018, but not specify for how long it will stick to this amount. We think it might then decide at its March 2018 meeting to cut to €20bn as of April. In June, it might then decide, depending on the data and market sentiment, to cut to zero as of July or extend the purchases in a modest way through Q3. Hence, tapering would last for 6-9 months, with aggregate purchases of c.€180-210bn. In line with the ECB's guidance, we expect key interest rates to be hiked only after the end of QE, most likely as of 2019

11:07 am
PM11:07am

Rates Strategy: How much ECB "patience, prudence and persistence" is priced?In our view the ECB has a strong incentive to preserve a high level of flexibility for its policy normalisation path as there are valid reasons for the ECB's gradualism. A reduction of QE purchases over 6-9 months remains our baseline, but the risks might be skewed towards a more gradual approach. Nonetheless, a significant QE extension at the current pace remains only mathematically possible and the hurdle for fundamental changes to the design of QE is likely very high in the absence of deflation risk. Euro area rates markets repriced monetary policy expectations significantly and parts of the rates spectrum shows exaggerated dovish expectations in our view. We take profit on our Jul-18 ECB-dated Eonia forwards position, would add to 1y1y vs 3y1y Eonia forward steepeners and would use the recent rally in German long-dated (real) yields to add to our strategic short duration view preferably expressed on regression against breakevens and cross market against US TIPS

PM11:07am

ECB news due out at 11.45 our time, I think, unless ive got my clocks wrong

PM11:08am

Bold prediction: No change

11:08 am
PM11:08am

That will do on that

undefined
PM11:09am

Just looking at Direct Line

11:08 am
PM11:09am

This is Ogden rate stuff, no?

BE11:09am

It is.

PM11:09am

Or whatever we call the new fangled discount rate for personal injury stuff

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Based on the evidence currently available the government would expect that if a single rate were set today under the new approach the real rate might fall within the range of 0% to 1%, but the new framework will only apply if the proposed law is enacted and will not operate retrospectively.

BE11:09am

That's Justice Secretary David Lidington

BE11:10am

Via the Ministry of Justice. And as of this moment it's all we know.

11:10 am
PM11:10am

There's an actual press release https://www.gov.uk...-payouts-announced

BE11:11am

So, Direct Line wins. Esure loses.

PM11:11am

Is that how it pans out?

11:11 am
PM11:11am

Reverses some of the damage seen earlier in the year

BE11:12am

Yep. Direct Line took the largest upfront hit on Ogden, followed by Admiral, so we're just assuming that'll reverse.

PM11:12am

(BBOC--- I stand corrected)

11:12 am
BE11:12am

JPM Caz can provide the specifics.

BE11:12am

With its FY16 results Direct Line took a
pretax loss of £217m on Ogden, while Admiral estimated the total net financial impact over several years at £140-175m. At the mid-point, an increase in the rate to +0.5% would be a 38% reversal of the previous change, although we note that the effects of the Ogden rate change are not linear and hence the improvement should be greater we believe, perhaps closer to half. For the other UK motor insurers (Hastings, Esure, Saga) the initial hit was smaller, therefore they have less to gain in our view. Other insurers that should also enjoy P&L gains are Ageas (took a €155m in FY16), and Aviva (£380m).

BE11:12am

Esure (N) at a slight disadvantage due to reinsurance renewal timing. We note that Esure has already renewed its excess-of-loss reinsurance (1 July) at an increase in cost of 33% on a risk adjusted basis. Others in the sector renew in January, and may see less of an increase due to this positive amendment now appearing more likely.

11:13 am
Direct Line Insurance Group PLC (DLG:LSE): Last: 381.90, up 10.3 (+2.77%), High: 389.70, Low: 374.20, Volume: 2.48m
Admiral Group PLC (ADM:LSE): Last: 1,843, down 32.5 (-1.73%), High: 1,866, Low: 1,785, Volume: 544.46k
esure Group PLC (ESUR:LSE): Last: 264.20, down 3.1 (-1.16%), High: 267.20, Low: 261.50, Volume: 217.02k
11:14 am
BE11:14am

Though none of this happens in a vacuum. Instead, it happens quite near the peak of the auto insurance pricing cycle, as we've said often.

BE11:14am

So, there's an offset. Back to Caz.

BE11:14am

The Ogden rate change has been a key driver of the positive pricing dynamics in the UK motor market, and so this change, if enacted, will arguably reduce the need for insurers to continue increasing pricing in the UK. We note that while the pricing environment is likely to slow as a result of this change, there is also a real cash cost to the industry that will reduce, so the aggregate effect on margins going forward could be broadly neutral.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

And UBS, adding a similar note of caution.

BE11:16am

Currently motor insurance market price increases are c9% in our view – which we see as likely sufficient to cover underlying claims inflation of 5% and the step change in the Ogden discount rate. As such, we would not expect a material change in pricing for 2017, but we may see a bit more competition coming back into the market – with risks accentuated into 2018 as reinsurance protection rolls off. We see this change, if enacted, as likely more positive for larger mature books (i.e. Direct Line, Admiral); who will need to put up prices up less at renewal, hence improving portfolio retention.

BE11:17am

Of course, we need to see the bill itself, and there's the possibility that it might not pass through Parliament (perhaps the Irish faction will be annoyed by the readthrough for whiplash claims -- who knows?)

11:18 am
PM11:18am

I was getting looking to get some fresh car insurance recently form a well known name. it seemed to be the case that unless I agreed to them spamming me and suck all my data, they wouldn't offer a quote. It's something I need to look into...

BE11:19am

U.K.’S CLARK SAID TO BE READY TO LEGISLATE FOR ENERGY PRICE CAP

PM11:20am

11:20 am

BE11:21am

BE11:22am

Then the language in the Queens Speech was vague to the point of abstraction. Market seems to be unfussed, which is probably the right response.

11:22 am
undefined
PM11:23am

Why's Imperial Brands suddenly popped upa t the top of the list??

BE11:23am

Several reasons. Well, three.

11:23 am
Imperial Brands PLC (IMB:LSE): Last: 3,300, up 90 (+2.80%), High: 3,320, Low: 3,290, Volume: 785.59k
PM11:24am

BATs also on the Footsie gainers screen as well

BE11:24am

First is the Logista selldown, which is as expected but helps things along in terms of the buyback.

11:24 am
BE11:25am

As in, selling 10% of Logista to cut its stake to 0% and raise around £244m, which it'll use as a one-off buyback fund.

BE11:25am

Actually, sorry, £160m in the buyback fund. Rest goes on debt.

BE11:26am

It's zero-sum for EPS and will do nearly nothing for the net debt (which is quite near 3x EBITDA) ....

11:26 am
BE11:27am

..... so the benefit is on the basis that Imperial's so cheap it may as well use its own cash to buy out its own shareholders.

BE11:27am

That's Jefferies' thesis, who (coincidentally) have a huge buy note out this morning.

BE11:27am

Here's the follow-up to that on the disposal specifically.

11:27 am
BE11:28am

Selling part of a stake in a non-core holding
to take advantage of this disparity and reward share holders should be applauded. What's
more, the fact that more of the funds were not set aside for debt pay-down shows the
continued strong cash generation and returns profile of the business. Cynics may have
argued that the move was done to prop up earnings but the fact the earnings impact is
neutral negates this argument. The one concern we do flag is the decision to put the money
into a buyback could imply no deals in the reduced risk space are imminent. We have argued
that given where sentiment is on Imperials positioning in emerging products they will need
to address this to really push the multiple on. We had hoped for a deal if they did take action.
If this means organic investment is more likely we would not be supportive of this (and could see de-rating on the back of such moves). There does however remain the option for M&A in the space as part of the China Tobacco JV (remember the release around this stated "Further tobacco and next generation launches, as well as potential M&A opportunities, will also be evaluated...")

BE11:28am

...... which brings us neatly into reason two .....

BE11:28am

Jefferies saying Imps is massively undervalued.

11:28 am
BE11:29am

While the headline multiple looks cheap, a sum of the parts shows the underlying valuation is cheaper still. With conservative assumptions on non core parts, we show the implied EV/EBITDA on the core cigarette business (c60% of EBITDA) is 7.4x. Assuming 10 year profit growth of -1.2% this would still then require a terminal decline of over 20%. Ardent bears will agree this is overly negative. Any positive news should drive re-rating at these levels.

BE11:29am

The
key driver of value for us, and as such the multiple on which Imperials overall valuation
should primarily be judged, is "returns" cigarettes, making up c60% of current EBITDA.
When applying a sum of the parts with conservative (bearish) assumptions to the other value
drivers, we show "returns" is trading on a trailing EV/EBITDA of 7.4x. On a DCF, if we assume
profit down on average 1.2% a year for the next 10 years, this would still then require a
negative terminal growth rate of -22% to get back to this valuation. Even the most ardent of
Imperial bears could easily conclude that such assumptions are overly negative. Looking at
Implied cigarette growth for valuations vs. peers further illustrates the extent of mispricing.

PM11:31am

This is a very confident call

11:30 am
BE11:31am

Market believes 34% discount to the sector because Reynolds is in permanent decline ....

PM11:31am

Goodness

BE11:31am

.... and is wrong, because Imps is more than just Reynolds, Jefferies says.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Imperials valuation is the sum of a number of uniquely different segments. A
large portion of its value is made up of non cigarettes, and even within cigarettes we can
identify three separate businesses with differing fundamentals. Until all these parts are split
out (in our view) we cannot form a true and accurate assessment of Imperials valuation.

BE11:32am

And, yeah, there's a bit about the JT bid that might arrive one day, maybe, and providing we keep writing about it every other week we can claim the scoop.

BE11:32am

While we think gains to be had from Imperial’s organic story (and re-rating) alone over
the next 12 months are attractive, we also believe a JT bid remains possible. Unlike other
observers, we think the FDA proposals around reducing nicotine make a bid for Imperial
more likely. The tobacco model if shifting to reduced risk products and the biggest driver
of this growth is likely to be the US. If JT is to keep pace with the likes of BAT and PMI,
getting appropriate distribution in the US to participate in this growth becomes even
more pressing. In addition, the added attraction for JT right now is that Imperial appears
to be largely undervalued.

11:32 am
BE11:33am

Which leads us nearly into reason three!

PM11:33am

...

BE11:33am

So, Japan looks like it's going to raise taxation on dork-pipes.

11:33 am
PM11:34am

dork-pipes?

BE11:34am

As in iQos and glo. The heat-not-burn pipes that are very very popular in Japan for a number of sociological and legal reasons.

PM11:00am

Welcome to Markets Live

11:34 am
BE11:35am

So PM and BAT have the dork-pipe market.

PM11:35am

(Ok, dont google "dork pipes")

PM11:35am

(Other wise IT might be on to you.)

11:35 am
BE11:35am

So, law by April 2018

BE11:35am

Citi with the numbers.

BE11:35am

Currently both Marlboro and iQos retail at ¥460, but lower taxes on
iQos mean PM’s net revenue is about 30% higher on iQos than on Marlboro.
(Figure 1). If tax on HNB is equalized with tax on cigarettes, we calculate the retail
price of iQos would have to be ¥508 to retain the same margin. (We think it is more
likely PM would pick ¥500 than ¥510.) We had already expected iQos volumes to
slow in 2018, but if retail prices do rise, the slowdown may be more rapid than we
are currently modelling. PM says it believes iQos consumers are not that price
sensitive as the product is so attractive, but we think it is too early to be sure of this.
PM could absorb some of the potential tax hike, but that would hit its sales hard.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

We expect iQos to add about 9
percentage points to PM’s global sales growth this year and 5 points in 2018 and
beyond, in large part because the net sales per unit volume is much greater for iQos
than for regular cigarettes. About 90% of iQos volumes are sold in Japan currently,
and iQos's market share of the total tobacco market reached 10% in 2Q17, up from
4.9% in 4Q16. Our model assumes iQos’s growth will slow in 2018 as its market
share will be about 20% and competition will intensify. Our current market share
assumptions in both Japan and Korea are shown in Figure 2 but if the tax rise does
go through there could be downside risk.

BE11:36am

(Sorry for the lack of Figs 1 and 2. They're too bitty for this forum.)

BE11:37am

For BAT, a tax increase is unhelpful but less important – We have argued that glo in Japan will add about 2 points to BAT’s organic sales growth in 2H17 and beyond. If this growth weakens, it is clearly unhelpful, but (1) BAT is still growing well in the conventional business (unlike PM), and (2) we believe there is nothing in BAT’s multiple for glo currently. (BAT trades at 15.6x 2018 EPS, vs 22.8x for PM on our numbers).

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Here's a good explainer of the Japanese tobacco market, in case anyone cares: https://www.ft.com...-90c0-90a9d1bc9691

British American Tobacco PLC (BATS:LSE): Last: 4,901, up 88.5 (+1.84%), High: 4,902, Low: 4,840, Volume: 639.38k

PM11:40am

Emma Mankarious, daughter and a PCA of Nabil Mankarious, acquired 250,000 Ordinary Shares at a price of 13.6p per Ordinary Share on 6 September 2017. Following this purchase, Emma Mankarious now has a total beneficial interest in 3,750,000 Ordinary Shares.

Shares went stratospheric after the Jurassic World Evolution announcement .....

Frontier Developments PLC (FDEV:LSE): Last: 1,210, up 90 (+8.04%), High: 1,210, Low: 1,200, Volume: 257.29k
PM11:43am

This has doubled in price in the space of a month

11:43 am
PM11:44am

Rocket

PM11:44am

There was also the Tencent investment, which we highlighted here

BE11:44am

Film game tie-ins delivered on a tight deadline have a ... let's say, a difficult track record.

11:44 am
BE11:45am

There are famous ones, like ET (as in, a few hundred thousand cartridges buried in a desert)

BE11:46am

But you've also got Eidos's long record of screwing up Tomb Raider releases rushed to meet film release deadlines.

BE11:47am

Anyway, I'm sure Frontier won't hit the same issues as basically every other video game maker ever.

11:46 am
BE11:47am

Here's Finncap on the figures.

PM11:47am

Yes, this is all true. But surely Braben knows this as well

PM11:47am

Go on , Finncap

11:47 am
PM11:47am

Joint broker

BE11:47am

Prelims confirm a highly successful year, whereby revenue grew by 75% to £37.4m and EBIT more dramatically, from £1.2m to £7.8m: comfortably ahead of previous guidance of “at least £7.2m”. Such strong growth in revenue and profit was achieved thanks to the launch of Planet Coaster (PC), with estimated sales of c.£20m. Now the development of Jurassic World Evolution (JW) is well underway and a further two titles in the early planning stages, we look forward to similar (and potentially more exaggerated and more frequent) step-ups in profit as Frontier looks to accelerate its strategy of launching and then maintaining carefully selected titles. We leave our forecasts essentially unchanged in both periods, but lift our target price to 1,332p.

BE11:47am

And Liberum.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

The shares have been very strong on the back of the announcement of Jurassic World Evolution (JWE) which has received major global interest and highlighted the long-term potential of the franchise business model. The Tencent investment will accelerate the opportunity in China. Full-year results show the encouraging performance of the first two franchises under a now proven self-publishing model. We leave our forecasts conservatively unchanged but raise our target price to 1250p given the potential major upside to revenues from the third franchise and beyond.

PM11:48am

Who are also join brokers

BE11:48am

(@wayneJ: agree entirely. A more civilised society would be building statues of David Braben.)

11:50 am
BE11:50am

(@wayneJ: though disagree a little on Eidos, which proved not terribly profitable for most shareholders. The lumpiness, sunk costs and unpredictable paybacks inherent in video game production were not ideal for the public markets at the time.)

BE11:50am

(@waynej: Perhaps public markets are better at that stuff now. Thumbs up )

undefined
11:51 am
PM11:51am

Guess we should mention the finals from Ashmore

PM11:51am

https://www.invest...1709070700030421Q/

BE11:52am

(@fjp73: true.)

11:51 am
PM11:52am

Run into some heavy selling this morning

Ashmore Group PLC (ASHM:LSE): Last: 341.80, down 23.4 (-6.41%), High: 359.80, Low: 318.90, Volume: 1.63m
PM11:52am

Is this justified?

11:52 am
PM11:53am

I thought they beat consensus?

PM11:53am

Clearly not

BE11:53am

They did, but it's low quality.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

As in, full of one-offs.

BE11:53am

And revenue's rubbish because fees are weak.

BE11:54am

Weaker net management fee margin, to use the preferred jargon.

11:54 am
PM11:55am

This is because more recent inflows have been tilted to institutional money...

PM11:55am

Squeezing margins

BE11:55am

Yeah, possibly. Larger mandates done at a cost.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

And AuM had been pre-announced so that's irrelevant. Divi was held, which was expected, so you're looking at the fee pressure and the non-recurring elements.

BE11:57am

Have Morgan Stanley, as we've quoted them yet this morning.

BE11:57am

Despite ~10% net new money during 2H17 (the first inflows since late 2013/early 2014) this has been at lower fee rates, with mgmt fee margins down ~10% H/H. Although MS and consensus forecast fee declines, the extent of declines 2H17 has surprised, which will likely drive consensus downgrades.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

Main disappointment is on management fees and, with assets and flows known, is owing to softer revenue margins. 2H17 fee rate of ~50bps is down ~10% H/H as, although the inflows recorded in the period have been into lower-margin institutional segregated mandates (this was known, we and consensus forecast margins to be down), the extent of the decline is worse than expected. Going forward, we model a further ~10% reduction over the next 4 years; however, we expect greater investor concern over the extent and pace of these declines given the new lower start point.

BE11:58am

Higher variable comp charge we view as one-off. Overall ~21-22% variable comp charge is above the company's stated 20% level, though, given: (i) significant fund outperformance vs. benchmark (~91% 1 year and ~86%/87% over 3-5 years); and (ii) strong seed capital gains realised in the period – we believe management has exercised discretion by increasing variable comp and would expect a normalisation in coming years.

undefined
11:58 am
PM11:58am

Euro still rising btw

PM11:58am

1.1985 on my screen

BE11:59am

Request for Go-Ahead, happy to help.

11:59 am
Go-Ahead Group PLC (GOG:LSE): Last: 1,607, down 145.91 (-8.32%), High: 1,728, Low: 1,578, Volume: 350.04k
BE11:59am

Consensus was too high going into numbers.

BE12:00pm

Which brokers are saying was stale, as in folk not updating in spite of the best efforts of the IR team.

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

So, we've got what looks a pretty aggressive pullback on numbers that, while unsurprising, don't seem to tell us much we don't already know.

BE12:02pm

Here's RBC.

BE12:02pm

l
l
l
l
l
l
l
l
2016/17E Operating profit of £150.6m vs. RBCe £146.7m, BBG cons £147.8m, PY £162.6m (53 week year)
Overall group revenues grew 3.6% to £3,481m, operating profits fell 7.4% to £150.6m with 4.3% (4.8%) margin.
DPS 102.8p (95.9p) (cons range 97.1p-122.6p) beating consensus but with cons affected by significant (bullish) outliers.
Selected ‘stale’ rail and DPS 2017/18 forecasts in consensus need to be revisited - RBCe rail EBIT 2017/18E already ~£25m, which we see higher end of consensus
range that is stale (at £41-45m) coming down due to weaker Southeastern trading, LMR exit. Outlier DPS prospect at 122p (+20% YoY) also need rethinking by select
forecasters we think.
We see total bus EBIT consensus 2017/18E likely to settle around £90-91m, but with lower interest and minority (rail) costs seeing RBCe last published EPS
2017/18E at 175.1p, implying a flat YoY DPS (if company takes a through rail bid cycle view).
Clean EPS 207.7p vs. BBG cons 208p (average)
Rail adjusted Net debt £285m vs. RBCe £308m.
Southeastern and other bids will be key to the DPS prospects but we see minimum 95-100p (5.5% mid-range yield) possible (on £91-92m bus EBIT, £4m German
rail EBIT prospects in time, GTR at £10-15m pa and with interest cost at £9-10m and tax at 17-20%).

12:02 pm
BE12:03pm

Our view on the shares – DPS delivers 5.8% yield. After the Q4 trading update saw a slight adverse (for value) mix change in EBIT, our SP rating reflects the likely
resistance in the shares after (summer 2017) adverse bus EBIT revisions (even with hope for better in 2017/18 in regional bus) and risk of eroding rail value in the short-term.

BE12:03pm

owever, we see DPS yield supported by UK Bus under normalised capex (for more detail see the 23/06/2017 note). We see part of total return supported by income but the
GTR contract creates an impediment to share performance – potentially until 2019 when the new operation is fully working (see Slide 31, 21/10/2014 Go-Ahead investor
event,) but we note that;
(1) Thameslink routes are now almost all Siemens class 700 operated – with the older class 319s having been exited – so product change is already under way.
(2) With a contract paid for operations not by commercial revenue (and thus UK GDP risk sits with the DFT instead), then industrial relations and infrastructure stability
should bring modest profits, cash generation and value – now potentially for another 6 years without market bid risk up to September 2023. Like with SGC LN – we see the
most predictable and thus valuable rail prospects (for shareholders and rail customers) in incumbent contract elongation – not new bids.
Go-Ahead shares trade at 10.4x 2017/18E PER vs. Go-Ahead 1997-2016 median PER of 10.9x and a 20-year ex rail PER of 12.8x. To move more positively we think the shares
would need to see trading deliver:
1) Bus profit stability (potentially challenging as the UK consumer wallows in debt with reducing consumer confidence but this may spur down trading from car use
too);
2) A better or more predictable GTR margin (likely from 2018/19 we think); and,
3) More DPS clarity (which we think the FY16/17 base will assist).
